You can accept, negotiate, probe for the trap, or refuse where others can see—knowing refusal is its own kind of insult.

outcomes.title: Accept Dutifully
outcomes.desc: Do the work, take the reward, swallow the taste.

success.text: You comply without complaint. They like that.

fail.text: You stumble, or hesitate, or disappoint. The smile stays. The hook sinks deeper.

outcomes.title: Set Terms
outcomes.desc: Make the price explicit so the debt is measurable.

success.text: You negotiate as an equal. They humor you—and pay.

fail.text: They decide you’ve forgotten your place.

outcomes.title: Investigate Motives
outcomes.desc: Find the knife hidden inside the gift.

success.text: You learn who the request harms—and why that matters.

fail.text: Your questions get noticed. Not punished—just watched.

outcomes.title: Decline Publicly
outcomes.desc: Keep your conscience. Pay in access.

success.text: The hall hears your refusal and calls it courage. The patron calls it inconvenient.

fail.text: You misstep, and the refusal becomes humiliation—yours.

name: Matchmaker’s Whisper
prompt: A matron with excellent memory and sharper etiquette draws you into a polite corner. She speaks of "a most suitable match"—names never quite said, intentions never quite confirmed. By the time you realize it, you’re already part of the evening’s entertainment: a possibility to be discussed, weighed, improved, or dismissed. In a hall like this, even rumors have teeth. You can play along, cut it cleanly, find the hand behind it, or turn the conversation into a weapon.

outcomes.title: Smile and Let It Spread
outcomes.desc: Treat it as flattering. A little attention can be useful—if you keep it on your terms.

success.text: You accept the insinuation with practiced ease—neither confirming nor denying, just letting the room imagine what it wants. Doors open when people believe you’re being "considered." You leave the feast slightly elevated, as if you’ve become worth watching for the right reasons.

fail.text: You push too hard, or smile too widely, and the room reads desperation where you meant poise. The whispers don’t stop—they sharpen. The evening ends with your name attached to an unflattering story that travels faster than you do.

outcomes.title: Find Who Benefits
outcomes.desc: A rumor this clean was polished by someone. Trace the hands that polished it.

success.text: You follow the small tells: who repeats the rumor, who corrects it, who waits to see your reaction. The trail leads to a petty faction’s leverage play—harmless on the surface, sharp beneath. You walk away with names and motives, which is to say: ammunition.

fail.text: The more you watch, the more you become watched. You spend the evening counting smiles and measuring pauses until your nerves feel raw. You learn little, and what you gain isn’t worth the fatigue.

outcomes.title: Refuse With Grace
outcomes.desc: Decline without insult. In a court, "no" is an art form.

success.text: You offer a refusal that sounds like principle instead of fear—calm, final, and impossible to argue with without looking small. The rumor loses oxygen. Some respect you for it. Some decide you’re harder to steer than they hoped.

fail.text: You say the right words in the wrong tone, or the wrong words at the wrong moment. The matron’s smile tightens. The room hears a slight where you meant restraint, and your access to certain circles cools for a while.

outcomes.title: Make It Someone Else’s Problem
outcomes.desc: Redirect the attention. If the hall wants a story, give it a better target than you.

success.text: You laugh softly, offer a carefully chosen compliment about someone *else*, and let the matchmaker’s instincts do the rest. Within minutes the room is chewing on a new narrative—one that keeps your name out of the sharpest parts. You leave richer in quiet leverage, and perhaps with a small gift pressed into your palm by someone grateful for your discretion.

fail.text: Your redirection is noticed. The matron’s eyes narrow—not angry, just assessing. You’ve demonstrated you can twist a room, and that makes you interesting in a dangerous way. People begin to watch you more closely than before.

name: Broken Wheel
prompt: The failure is sudden and final: a crack like a snapped bone, then the sickening tilt of your cart—or the sag of a pack rig—dumping weight into the mud. The sun is already dropping, and the road ahead is the kind that grows teeth after dusk. You can hear distant life on the wind: a dog barking, a wagon far off, maybe nothing at all. Whatever you decide, it has to happen now. Night does not negotiate.

outcomes.title: Fix It Yourself
outcomes.desc: Kneel in the dirt, take stock of the damage, and make something hold with wood, rope, and stubborn focus.

success.text: You strip the rig down to its essentials and rebuild it into something uglier but functional. The repair won’t impress anyone, but it will carry you. You’re back on the road before the last light fully dies, and the small victory feels like saving your own life with your hands.

fail.text: The break is worse than it looked. A peg splinters, a knot slips, and each failed attempt costs you more rope, more patience, more daylight. When you finally give up, you’ve lost precious materials and gained the heavy fatigue of fighting the inevitable.

outcomes.title: Muscle Through
outcomes.desc: Abandon comfort and carry what you can. If the road won’t take the weight, your body will.

success.text: You lash what remains into a crude harness and haul it forward step by step. It’s brutal, but it works. Someone sees you—traveler, farmer, guard—and the sight of sheer refusal to stop becomes a story that follows you. You arrive sore, poorer in provisions, richer in reputation.

fail.text: You try to brute-force the road into obedience and it answers with pain. A strap bites, a load shifts, and you take a hard twist or a crushing stumble. You make it out, but the injury lingers—an insult you’ll carry longer than the gear you saved.

outcomes.title: Borrow What You Need
outcomes.desc: Find a nearby traveler or homestead and ask as if it’s reasonable—because sometimes confidence is half the bargain.

success.text: You speak plainly, offer a promise that sounds like it will be kept, and make your need feel shared rather than begged. A wheelwright’s scrap, a spare peg, a length of cord—small mercies, but enough. You leave with a repaired rig and a thin thread of goodwill you can tug again later.

fail.text: Your request lands wrong: too bold, too needy, too entitled. Doors close, faces tighten, and you feel the social temperature drop. Even if you find a workaround, you walk away with the sting of being refused in a way others will remember.

outcomes.title: Steal a Replacement
outcomes.desc: If it’s unattended, it’s yours. Survival is a better excuse than pride.

success.text: You find what you need behind a shed or beside a sleeping wagon: a spare wheel, a usable yoke, a bundle of cordage. You take it quickly and leave nothing but absence. The repair is almost elegant in how neatly it solves your problem—and how neatly it creates a new one if you’re ever recognized.

fail.text: A lantern swings. Someone wakes. A voice calls out, and suddenly your ‘quick theft’ becomes an accusation with witnesses. You get away, but the road gains one more story about you—one the wrong people might take seriously.

name: Snowed-In Pass
prompt: The pass disappears under fresh snowfall as if the mountain has decided you don’t deserve to cross. Wind cuts the breath out of you. The world narrows to white, stone, and the cruel arithmetic of cold. Waiting means burning supplies and time. Pushing forward means risking the slope, the drop, the sudden silence of a buried path. Somewhere nearby, smoke might mean shelter—or strangers who won’t ask nicely before taking what you have.

outcomes.title: Climb Through
outcomes.desc: Force your way over the teeth of the mountain. No delay. No retreat.

success.text: You lead yourself like a stubborn animal: step, breath, step. You find footholds where none should exist and refuse to let the cold bargain with you. When you crest the worst of it, the world opens again. Later, people talk about the one who crossed when the pass said no.

fail.text: The mountain takes payment. You stumble through drifts that swallow your legs, fight wind that steals your warmth, and keep moving long after you should have stopped. You survive—but you come out hollowed, shaking, and deeply spent.

outcomes.title: Chart a Detour
outcomes.desc: Accept the delay and choose the route that kills you slower.

success.text: You read the land the way you read a page—looking for the parts that repeat and the parts that lie. You find a longer route that stays lower and calmer. It costs you time and provisions, but you keep your bones intact and your odds intact.

fail.text: Your ‘detour’ becomes a slow trap: false turns, dead ends, and exposed stretches where the wind punishes every mistake. By the time you find anything like a workable path, you’ve eaten through far more than you planned.

outcomes.title: Sneak Into a Lodge
outcomes.desc: Warmth stolen is still warmth. Slip inside, take what you need, leave before dawn.

success.text: You find the lodge by smoke and silhouette. A window latch gives, a door yields, and you tuck yourself into borrowed heat. You eat something hot, dry your layers, and leave before anyone wakes. Whatever fatigue was chewing at you loosens its grip—at least for now.

fail.text: A board creaks like a shout. A dog barks. A voice demands to know who’s there. You flee into the snow with the sting of attention behind you—someone has a reason to remember you now, and they may share it.

outcomes.title: Treat With Locals
outcomes.desc: Pay for a roof and a bowl. Let hospitality be bought instead of stolen.

success.text: You approach openly, offer coin without posturing, and speak like a person who understands that winter is everyone’s enemy. They take you in—not lovingly, but pragmatically. You leave fed, resupplied, and with a small thread of goodwill in a place where goodwill is usually scarce.

fail.text: Your offer is taken as insult or suspicion. Maybe you smell like trouble. Maybe you look too capable. Maybe they simply can’t afford another mouth. You pay anyway—coin spent for nothing—and walk away with a small, public rejection that doesn’t feel good in a cold place.

name: Campfire Visitors
prompt: Your fire is a beacon, and beacons draw ships—sometimes wrecks. Footsteps approach beyond the light’s edge. A few figures emerge with palms open and voices soft. They claim to be travelers. They might be. They might also be hungry, desperate, armed, or simply opportunistic. In the dark, intent is hard to read. The choice you make now decides whether this night becomes a story you tell… or one told about you.

outcomes.title: Share the Fire
outcomes.desc: Offer warmth, a little food, and the dignity of being treated like human beings. Trust is a gamble—sometimes it pays.

success.text: You make space and set clear boundaries—firm, but not cruel. The strangers relax, and the conversation becomes ordinary: roads, weather, warnings. One of them repays your generosity with a small favor, a useful connection, or a promise that feels sincere. You sleep more deeply than expected, the tension easing out of your shoulders.

fail.text: Hospitality invites appetite. While you look at one face, another hand drifts toward your pack. By the time you notice, something is gone—food, rope, a small necessity you only miss when it matters. They vanish back into the dark, leaving you with embers and loss.

outcomes.title: Question Them Carefully
outcomes.desc: Keep them talking. People reveal themselves when you ask the right thing at the right time.

success.text: You ask about landmarks that don’t exist, villages that burned years ago, a bridge that was never built—and watch the answers. The lies come out uneven, and the truth shows through the cracks. You learn who they are, what they want, and what road ahead is dangerous. When they leave, you’re still cautious, but you’re also better prepared—and you salvage a little extra from the encounter.

fail.text: The conversation drags. They dodge, you probe, they probe back. The night becomes a tense negotiation that never fully resolves. Even if no blade is drawn, you don’t sleep—at least not properly—and you wake with your nerves worn thin.

outcomes.title: Send Them Away
outcomes.desc: Draw a line and hold it. Make it clear the fire is not communal.

success.text: You rise, square your shoulders, and make your refusal unmistakable. The strangers weigh you and decide this camp isn’t worth the trouble. They fade back into the trees, and the message carries: you are not easy prey.

fail.text: Your refusal becomes the spark. One of them steps too close, and suddenly it’s hands and knives in firelight. You drive them off, but not cleanly. When the dark goes quiet again, you’re left with a fresh hurt and the sour knowledge of how close that came to worse.

outcomes.title: Slip Away First
outcomes.desc: Leave no trace, no target. Let them find an empty fire and nothing else.

success.text: You douse the coals, pack quickly, and vanish into the dark before they’re close enough to commit. You learn a useful truth about the road—how quickly danger forms around comfort—and you carry that lesson forward like a private advantage.

fail.text: In your hurry, you lose time and gear. A strap snaps, a bundle spills, footsteps quicken behind you. You escape, but the night taxes you anyway—taking food and necessities as the price for staying alive.

name: The Toll Road
prompt: A rope across the road, a crude gate, and a man with a ledger that looks a little too clean for the mud around him. He claims official authority, names a lord you’ve heard of, and flashes papers that are plausible at a glance and suspicious on the second look. Behind him stand a few hard-eyed ‘assistants’ who don’t smile. Whether he’s legitimate or a thief in ink-stained clothing, he wants coin. The road is narrow. Turning back costs time. Going forward costs something else.

outcomes.title: Pay and Pass
outcomes.desc: Sometimes you buy peace. Hand over coin and move on before it becomes a conversation.

success.text: You pay without drama and keep your eyes forward. The tollkeeper grins like a man who has won, but you keep your life uncomplicated. The road opens, and you take the small victory of continuing uninjured and uninterrupted.

fail.text: You pay—and still they take something from the exchange. A sneer, a comment meant to belittle, a moment where bystanders see you ‘comply’ and file it away as weakness. It isn’t a real wound, but it stings in the social way that can linger.

outcomes.title: Demand Proof
outcomes.desc: Make them show their hand. Real officials don’t mind scrutiny—fake ones hate it.

success.text: You ask the right questions: which office issued the writ, what seal should look like up close, what the toll is ‘supposed’ to fund. The tollkeeper stumbles, and the assistants shift in a way that answers you more clearly than words. You walk away not just past the gate, but with useful knowledge—names, methods, tells you can use again.

fail.text: You argue until your breath fogs and your patience frays. They don’t crack; they simply waste your time with practiced certainty and vague threats. You leave—one way or another—feeling like you spent an hour wrestling a wall.

outcomes.title: Threaten the Fraud
outcomes.desc: Force the gate with reputation and steel. Make them believe this is the wrong road to die on.

success.text: You step close enough that they have to measure you honestly. Your voice carries the promise of consequence, and your posture suggests you’ve delivered on worse promises before. They back down, not bravely, but pragmatically. You take the road and a small gain from their scattered ‘toll’ stores—because they’re too eager to let you go to argue over it.

fail.text: The tollkeeper’s assistants are waiting for someone to be brave. When you push, they push back. You get through, but you pay in pain—a quick blow, a hard shove, a cut you didn’t have a moment earlier.

outcomes.title: Forge Your Own Pass
outcomes.desc: Meet fraud with fraud. Give them paperwork that makes their paperwork irrelevant.

success.text: You produce a document that looks official enough to intimidate a liar—names, dates, the right kind of confidence. For a heartbeat, the tollkeeper doubts themselves, and doubt is all you need. The rope lifts, and you pass while they’re still deciding whether to challenge you. The trick teaches you something valuable about how authority is faked.

fail.text: They recognize the bluff—or decide to treat any bluff as an excuse for violence. Your ‘pass’ becomes evidence, and their attention sharpens into a kind of pursuit that doesn’t require proof to be dangerous.

name: Crumbling Shrine
prompt: A roadside shrine leans like an old man who refuses to sit. Weather has gnawed the carvings smooth. The offering bowl still holds a few coins, a ribbon, a small charm of wood and wire. Someone still cares enough to leave something—yet no one cares enough to repair it. The air is quiet in that specific way that makes you feel watched, even if there’s nothing there. You can honor the place, study it, steal from it, or leave it to rot as the world does.

outcomes.title: Restore It
outcomes.desc: Set stones back into place, clear the ruin, and leave the shrine better than you found it—if only by a little.

success.text: You work with patient hands: stacking stones, sweeping debris, righting what can be righted. It isn’t grand, but it’s real. Later, someone passes and sees the shrine standing straighter, and they remember that someone cared. If your name has been bruised, this quiet act smooths it—because sincerity is hard to argue with.

fail.text: The work takes more out of you than expected. Cold stone, stiff joints, and the slow grind of effort without immediate reward. You manage something, but not enough to feel finished, and you leave with fatigue clinging to you like dust.

outcomes.title: Study the Carvings
outcomes.desc: Trace the worn symbols and old prayers. Faith leaves patterns—even when people forget why.

success.text: You find meaning in the weathered lines: a regional mark, a half-erased name, a devotional phrase tied to a larger tradition. The shrine isn’t just a broken roadside trinket—it’s connected. The knowledge gives you a small foothold in the networks of belief and charity that keep the world stitched together.

fail.text: You linger too long in damp air and cold stone shadow. Whether it’s chill, mold, or bad luck, something settles into your lungs and bones. You walk away with a cough that wasn’t there before.

outcomes.title: Take the Offerings
outcomes.desc: Need makes thieves of saints. If the world won’t provide, you’ll provide for yourself.

success.text: You lift the coins and the small usable items with practiced speed, telling yourself it’s only metal and food and nobody will miss it. The gain is immediate and practical. The discomfort comes later, in the quiet moment when you remember someone left those offerings for a reason.

fail.text: A passerby sees you with your hand in the bowl. Or you fumble, making noise where there should be reverence. However it happens, the act becomes known—and people are strangely unforgiving about theft when it wears the mask of sacrilege.

outcomes.title: Leave It Alone
outcomes.desc: Walk on without touching what isn’t yours. Let the shrine keep whatever dignity it has left.

success.text: You offer nothing but restraint, and sometimes that’s the cleanest gift. You move on with your conscience quieter than it might have been, and the road feels a little less heavy.

fail.text: You leave it behind. The world does not reward you for it—at least not today.

name: An Old Veteran’s Tale
prompt: A scarred veteran speaks like someone who has stopped pretending the world is fair. They offer lessons—for coin, for respect, or for a favor you won’t understand until later. Their stories are entertaining, but the useful parts are the ones they don’t dramatize: small decisions made under pressure, and the ways people lie to themselves to keep moving.

outcomes.title: Pay for Lessons
outcomes.desc: Spend coin to buy hard-earned clarity.

success.text: You leave with a handful of tricks and a quieter fear of the obvious.

fail.text: You pay and learn less than you hoped. The disappointment follows you home.

outcomes.title: Earn It in Sparring
outcomes.desc: Prove you’re worth the time.

success.text: You take bruises and turn them into respect.

fail.text: You take the wrong bruise. The lesson arrives in pain.

outcomes.title: Ask What He Won’t Brag About
outcomes.desc: Get the truths hidden between the heroic parts.

success.text: He gives you names, dates, and the quiet shape of old betrayals.

fail.text: He resents the questions and makes you feel it.

outcomes.title: Flatter Him Into Talking
outcomes.desc: Let pride loosen the locked parts of the story.

success.text: He boasts. You listen. You leave richer than you look.

fail.text: He sees through it and decides you’re the kind of person who’d sell a friend’s name.

name: Sealed Coffer
prompt: You find a sealed coffer with no crest and no explanation. It doesn’t hum with magic. It hums with *importance*—the kind that gets couriers killed and makes honest men lie. The lock is clean. The wood is old. Whoever owned it expected it to arrive somewhere, and it did not.

outcomes.title: Pick the Lock
outcomes.desc: Quiet hands, quick answers.

success.text: You open it without breaking the seal. Inside: coin and a hint of the story it belonged to.

fail.text: You fumble and leave evidence. Someone will know the coffer was touched.

outcomes.title: Break It Open
outcomes.desc: Noise now. Profit now.

success.text: Splinters fly. The contents spill. You take the coin and pretend you never wondered who it was for.

fail.text: The lid gives way badly. You cut yourself and draw the wrong kind of attention.

outcomes.title: Deliver It for a Fee
outcomes.desc: Let honesty be a service you sell.

success.text: You return it to someone who looks relieved and annoyed in equal measure. They pay you to leave quickly.

fail.text: They accept it—and treat you like part of the problem that delivered it.

outcomes.title: Hide It Briefly
outcomes.desc: Keep it for a moment when you need leverage.

success.text: You stash it somewhere safe enough to calm your nerves—unsafe enough to keep you thinking about it.

fail.text: You pick the wrong place, or someone picks you. The coffer becomes a spotlight.

name: Scribe’s Error
prompt: A mistake in ink can ruin you as thoroughly as a blade. Somewhere in a ledger, your name has been placed where it doesn’t belong—taxes you don’t owe, a crime you didn’t commit, a debt that isn’t yours. The people who trust paper more than faces will treat the record as truth. Correcting it means time, politics, and patience. Ignoring it means consequences that compound. And the quietest solution—the one done with forged strokes—risks becoming a crime of your own.

outcomes.title: Correct the Record
outcomes.desc: Fix it properly, in daylight. Bring evidence, endure the clerks, and make the ink obey reality.

success.text: You gather proof, chase stamps, and corner the right clerk at the right hour. The correction is slow, but it lands. A line is scratched out. A new line replaces it. The world becomes marginally safer because the paper agrees with you again.

fail.text: The office resists you with a thousand small refusals: ‘come back tomorrow,’ ‘wrong counter,’ ‘missing seal.’ Whether incompetence or malice, it eats your day and leaves you drained, with nothing resolved.

outcomes.title: Pay to Make It Go Away
outcomes.desc: Coin buys silence and stamps. It’s unfair, but it’s fast.

success.text: You pay the ‘fee’ that isn’t written anywhere official and watch the clerk’s attitude soften instantly. The record doesn’t become righteous—it becomes quiet. Your coin disappears, but so does the worst of the social stink clinging to your name.

fail.text: You pay, and the office still finds a way to take more. The mistake remains half-alive, and now you’ve also spent coin you couldn’t spare. The problem becomes a debt-shaped shadow that follows you out the door.

outcomes.title: Alter It Quietly
outcomes.desc: A little ink, a big change. If the system lies about you, lie back—better.

success.text: You pick a moment when the office is distracted and the right ledger is unattended. A careful smudge, a rewritten line, a number that becomes a different number. The record agrees with you again, and you walk away with the private knowledge that paper is only as honest as the hand holding the pen.

fail.text: Someone sees the movement of your hand or notices the wrong kind of confidence in your posture. The ledger snaps shut like a trap, and suspicion attaches itself to you. Even if you escape, the danger has a new, official flavor.

outcomes.title: Endure the Consequences
outcomes.desc: Take the hit and outlast the record. Survive the paperwork long enough to fix it later.

success.text: You absorb the indignity, keep your head down when needed, and refuse to let the mistake define you. People see you endure and keep functioning anyway, and that stubborn steadiness becomes its own kind of respect. You mark a future moment to correct this properly—when you have the time, leverage, and strength to finish the fight.

fail.text: The consequences compound faster than your patience. A missed payment becomes a penalty; a penalty becomes a demand; a demand becomes a threat. By the time you realize you can’t simply ‘endure,’ the mistake has grown teeth—and you are drowning in it.
